title: Hookes law-new spring length after changing masses

content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is hanging in equilibrium from a spring. The block stretches the spring to length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The block is removed, and the spring returns to its unstretched length of <math alttext="the fraction 3 L, over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>L</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. If a larger block with mass <math alttext="4 m " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mi>m</mi></math> is hung from the spring and slowly lowered until it is in equilibrium, what will the new length of the spring be?

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
